components.name: CreditsComponent
components.templateData:
Credits

Production

Game Design: Guillermo Mura (@Sanscripter)
Code: Guillermo Mura (@Sanscripter)

Assets

https://www.publicdomainpictures.net/ - Public Domain Pictures
https://opengameart.org/ - Public Domain Game Art
https://unsplash.com/ - Unsplash Free Use Pictures
https://www.goodfreephotos.com/ - Public Domain Pictures
https://www.chosic.com/ - Public Domain Music
https://giventofly.github.io/pixelit/ - pixelit to modify images to pixel art

Special Thanks

Esther Campos Mura

- for being an amazing wife and right by my side during the development

Kaique

- for brainstorming mechanics and visual ideas with me during some deep talks

FefoNeto

- for great UI review and ideas on the map (and being generally disgusting and punchable)

components.name: EndScreenComponent
components.templateData:
Game Over

@if (ending === endings.DIED) {

You rest your face on the sand and feel every limb of your body go numb, one by one, from the extremities inwards. You close your eyes and swallow in a vain attempt to hydrate your throat, as though you prepared to state your case to a higher power to let you live. You present eloquently how much you still have to achieve, what other lives you will impact, the justice you will bring and how you will honor your father's legacy. But, alas, your silent inner-monologue falls on deaf ears and you feel the mantle of darkness cover you whole with, putting a surprisingly tender end to a rough and unforgiving life.

} @else if (ending === endings.PAID) {

As the 30th day gives in to the night, you return to the place where you first buried your father. Thirteen lights rip through the night, getting closer. You count your money and ready an envelope. The riders stop around the station but leave their engines running, except for one who hops off his motorbike and walks towards you. No words, he just stands his hand in your general direction and you give him the money. He opens up. He counts. Everything is there - but it's also everything you've got. "You did good, kid.", he says, "Take it it easy for a few days and we'll call you with your next assignment". That takes you by surprise - your original understanding was that after the debt was paid you'd be free to go your own way. "We are going to have a prosperous future together", the man continues, raising his hand again expecting you to shake it, "what do you say?". You consider spitting on it or turning away or at the very least saying "No" but you quicly look around: they came in numbers and are all well armed. You are in no position to refuse, because of the implication. You shake hands, they leave setting dust off in the air. You sit on the ground, near your father's grave and spend the night awake looking at the horizon. That line, that perimiter where the sky clashed with the edge of Happy Valley, that line became the fence around the rest of your life. You watch the sun rise but it feels indistinguishable from a cell now.

} @else if (ending === endings.RICH) {

The day has come. You set up a meeting with the leader of Los Treze in the same place your father was once burried. He arrives early. You never do. Instead, using your newly accumulated wealth, you hire 7 mercenaries as a welcome comitee. You never learn just quite what happened that day, only that the Los Treze dissolved shortly after and the mercenaries assured you nobody would be messing with you anymore. With the remaining wealth you are able to recruit some survivors from around Happy Valley and found a settlement of your own. Over the years, as civilisation regrows, it becomes the capital of the first democratic proto-state of the New World and your natural ability as a trader becomes instrumental in bringing abundance and prosperity to the region.

} @else if (ending === endings.INSOLVENT) {

Days go by and before you realize the sun sets on the 30th day. You know you are short and you consider running, leaving Happy Valley, taking a chance somewhere else. Unfortunately, by the time you settled on a plan and hit the road with what you have, a van followed by 12 motrocylcles finds and ambushes you. No words are exchanged - none are needed. You resign to your fate and let them put you on the back of the van. The last thing you see in life is the start-sprangled night sky through the van's window, upside-down, 2-inches away from the rest of your bruised body.

}

Stats

components.name: HeaderComponent
components.template:
Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
components.sourceCode:
import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { ButtonComponent } from './button.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, ButtonComponent], template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: MusicButtonComponent
PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { HeaderComponent } from './header.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, HeaderComponent], template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }

components.name: StartScreenComponent
components.templateData:
@if (!triggerWarningConsent) {

Warning

This game contains strong language, mild violence, and drug use. It also contains mentions of torture, psychological distress, and suicide. This content may be disturbing or triggering to some individuals. This game is a fictional work of art (arguably) and should not be a substitute for proper education or real-world understanding. The characters, events, and ideas portrayed in this game are purely fictional and do not reflect real-world beliefs or actions. Please approach the content with critical thinking and discretion. It is important to remember that this is a game meant for entertainment and debate purposes only, and any replication of the ideas or actions of characters within the game is strongly discouraged. Use your judgment responsibly. Please do not play this game if you are under 18 years old, or if you are currently experiencing psychological distress, depression, or suicidal thoughts. This game contains mild-political commentary. Again, player discretion is advised.

} @else {

In the distant future of 2004,

@if (currentSlide === 0) {

30 years after the escalation of global conflict wiped 86% of man-kind, people of the world - what's left of them - have abandoned the underground shelters they have called home for so long. The surface is now a barren wasteland with limited natural resources that are contested by new factions, forged in the fires of a new world. Amidst the conflict, a new class emerged, out of the need to transport essential goods in the now lawless plains that separate the few remanning human settlements - the Trade Runners. These brave men and women risk their lifes the Dead Zones looking for opportunities to make a substantial profit trading food, medicine, tools and more.

} @if (currentSlide === 1) {

Your father was one such Runner. He drove both of you to Happy Valley, a valley surrounded by mountains, home to a group of rapidly expanding settlements and many, many opportunities. He got a loan from a local gang, Los Treze, to start your new life, but something happened. He lost a shipment in a raid and was unable to make his payments. One day, coming back to camp from ressuply, you find your dad on the ground, decapitated . His head is impaled at the entrance of your tent. His teeth are cleched on a piece of paper. You remove and unwrap it. It's note from the killers "100 grand. In 30 days. Or you're next". You hold a simple funeral, pack up your things and start looking for the first settlement to trade with...

} @if (currentSlide === 2) {
}
@if (currentSlide !== 0) { } @if (currentSlide !== 2) { }
}
